questions.text: What condition can lead to the characteristic waveform on capnography displayed by a patient under general anesthesia as observed on the ET CO2 monitor? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bronchospasm

 

Shark Fin appearance seen in bronchospasm due to anaphylaxis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Malignant hyperthermia:

 

 

Option C. Rebreathing:

 

 

Option D. Accidental extubation

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Shark Fin appearance seen in bronchospasm is due to anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Jackson Rees circuit is used in: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pediatric controlled ventilation

 

Jackson Rees circuit (also known as Mapleson F circuit) is specifically designed for:

 

  • Pediatric patients
  • Can be used for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation in children
  • It's a modification of the Ayre's T-piece with an open-ended bag
  • This circuit is ideal for pediatric anesthesia due to its low resistance and minimal dead space

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Adult controlled ventilation: Not appropriate as Jackson Rees circuit is designed for pediatric patients. Adults require circuits with larger volumes and different configurations.

 

Option C. Obstetric ventilation: Obstetric patients require specialized circuits that can deliver high flow rates and manage rapid changes in ventilation demands.

 

Option D. Cardiac patients: Cardiac patients typically require precise control over ventilation parameters, which is better achieved with more sophisticated circuits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Jackson Rees circuit (Mapleson F) is specifically designed and used for pediatric anesthesia, suitable for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation.

questions.text: Which nerve is blocked in the following local anesthesia technique shown in the image below? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nasociliary nerve

 

  • Anatomy: The nasociliary nerve is a branch of the ophthalmic nerve, which is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V).
  • Procedure: The needle is inserted 1 cm superior and 1.5 cm posterolateral to the medial canthal ligament of the eye. A maximum of 2 mL of local anesthetic solution is then slowly injected.
  • Use: This nerve block is used in procedures such as septoplasty, rhinoplasty, and the treatment of nasal bone fractures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior ethmoidal nerve: The anterior ethmoidal nerve is another branch of the ophthalmic nerve. It innervates the anterior and middle ethmoidal air cells and part of the nasal cavity, but it is not targeted by the described technique.

 

Option C. Sphenopalatine nerve: The sphenopalatine nerve, also known as the nasopalatine nerve, is a branch of the maxillary nerve (another branch of the trigeminal nerve). It supplies the nasal septum and the anterior part of the hard palate, but the described technique does not target this nerve.

 

Option D. Greater palatine nerve: The greater palatine nerve is also a branch of the maxillary nerve. It innervates the hard palate and the palatal gingiva, and is not targeted by the described technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The nasociliary nerve block involves inserting a needle superior and posterolateral to the medial canthal ligament of the eye and injecting a local anesthetic solution. This technique is primarily used for procedures involving the nasal area, such as septoplasty, rhinoplasty, and nasal bone fracture treatment.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2413-2414

questions.text: How long should elective surgery be deferred for a patient who had cough and fever, after he has recovered from COVID-19, and has not required any hospitalization?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6 weeks

 

Elective surgery deferral based on respiratory disease severity and COVID-19 recovery:

 

  • 4 weeks: For an asymptomatic patient with mild respiratory symptoms.
  • 6 weeks: For a symptomatic patient who did not need hospital treatment.
  • 8 weeks: For a symptomatic patient who was hospitalized in the ward.
  • 12 weeks: For a patient who was admitted to the intensive care unit due to respiratory infection.

 

Application:

 

  • As this patient was symptomatic but did not need hospitalization, elective surgery can be deferred for 6 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 8-10 weeks: This timeline is recommended for symptomatic patients who were hospitalized in the ward, which does not apply to this patient.

 

Option C. 12 weeks: This timeline is for patients who were admitted to the intensive care unit due to a respiratory infection, which also does not apply to this patient.

 

Option D. 4 weeks: This timeline is for asymptomatic patients with mild respiratory symptoms, which is not the case for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Elective surgery should be deferred for 6 weeks in a patient who had cough and fever due to COVID-19 but did not require hospitalization. This ensures sufficient recovery time to reduce perioperative risks.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2423

questions.text: In conventional oxygen therapy, which device will deliver the highest FiO2? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Non-rebreathing mask

 

  • FiO2 Delivery: A non-rebreathing mask can deliver an FiO2 of up to 80% at flow rates of 10-15 L/min. This mask has a reservoir bag that fills with oxygen and a one-way valve that prevents the exhaled air from entering the reservoir bag, ensuring a higher concentration of oxygen is inhaled.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venturi mask: The Venturi mask delivers a precise FiO2, which can range from 24% to 66%, depending on the entrainment device used. It is often used in patients who require a specific oxygen concentration.

 

Option B. Hudson mask: This option appears to refer to a simple face mask, which can deliver up to 60% FiO2 at 10 L/min. It is less efficient in delivering high concentrations of oxygen compared to a non-rebreathing mask.

 

Option D. Nasal cannula: A nasal cannula typically delivers up to 44% FiO2 at a flow rate of 6 L/min. It is comfortable and used for patients who need low to moderate oxygen supplementation but cannot deliver the high concentrations achievable with a non-rebreathing mask.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The non-rebreathing mask delivers the highest FiO2 in conventional oxygen therapy, capable of providing up to 80% FiO2 at flow rates of 10-15 L/min, making it suitable for patients requiring high concentrations of oxygen.

choices.text: Check carotid pulse, start CPR, and call for help, Defibrillate if no pulse.
Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse

questions.text: On your evening walk in the park, you notice an unconscious man lying on the ground. What would you do next? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse

 

Explanation:

 

Call for help, check pulse, do CPR, defibrillate if no pulse: This is the recommended sequence in most bystander situations. Firstly, ensure scene safety (make sure you're not putting yourself or the individual in further danger). Then, call for help or ask someone nearby to do so. This ensures that professional medical help is on the way. After calling for help, you’d check the pulse and breathing. If the person is not breathing and/or doesn’t have a pulse, you would start CPR. If an Automated External Defibrillator (AED) is available and the person doesn’t have a pulse, you would use it as soon as possible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Check carotid pulse, start CPR, and call for help, Defibrillate if no pulse: While checking the pulse and starting CPR is correct, calling for help first ensures that professional medical assistance is on the way, which is crucial for the best chance of survival.

 

Option C. Observe: This is not the recommended approach. Immediate intervention is critical when someone is unconscious, especially if they are not breathing or lack a pulse. Delays in initiating CPR or calling for help can drastically reduce the chance of survival and increase the potential for permanent injury.

 

Option D. Ignore and continue to walk: This is not an ethical or appropriate response when encountering someone in potential distress. Immediate action can make the difference between life and death.

 

Educational Objective :

 

In an emergency situation where someone is unconscious, the immediate steps should be to call for help, check for a pulse and breathing, start CPR if needed, and use a defibrillator if available and the person has no pulse.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 2715-2716

questions.text: IV anesthetic agent that causes adrenocortical suppression is: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Etomidate

 

Etomidate causes adrenocortical suppression by inhibiting the 11-beta hydroxylase enzyme in the adrenal cortex. This enzyme is responsible for steroid production in the body. When etomidate inhibits this enzyme, it reduces steroid production, which can lead to adrenocortical suppression. Due to this effect, etomidate should be avoided in critically ill or septic patients where maintaining adequate steroid levels is important for hemodynamic stability.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Propofol: Does not cause adrenocortical suppression. It acts mainly through GABA receptors and affects the central nervous system.

 

Option C. Thiopentone: A barbiturate that acts on GABA receptors but does not affect adrenal function or steroid synthesis.

 

Option D. Ketamine: An NMDA receptor antagonist that actually stimulates the sympathetic system and may increase steroid levels rather than suppress them.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Etomidate causes adrenocortical suppression by inhibiting 11-beta hydroxylase enzyme in the adrenal cortex, making it unsuitable for use in critically ill or septic patients who require normal steroid function.

choices.text: Increased nicotine levels may elevate sympathetic tone.
Increased carboxyhaemoglobin levels may cause a rightward shift in the oxyhaemoglobin dissociation curve.
Reduced pulmonary capacity can result from diminished ciliary function and decreased surfactant production.
The risk of infection is heightened due to impaired immune function.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the impact of smoking on a chronic smoker scheduled for elective surgery is incorrect? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased carboxyhaemoglobin levels may cause a rightward shift in the oxyhaemoglobin dissociation curve.

 

Smoking increases carboxyhaemoglobin levels, which causes a leftward shift of the oxygen dissociation curve. This leftward shift means hemoglobin holds onto oxygen more tightly, impairing oxygen delivery to tissues. Smoking cessation for at least 12 hours before surgery decreases carboxyhaemoglobin levels, shifting the curve rightward and improving tissue oxygenation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased nicotine levels may elevate sympathetic tone: Nicotine stimulates sympathetic activity, which increases the risk of arrhythmias during anesthesia. Reduced nicotine levels from smoking cessation decrease this risk.

 

Option C. Reduced pulmonary capacity can result from diminished ciliary function and decreased surfactant production:  Smoking impairs ciliary function, increases mucus production, and reduces surfactant, leading to reduced pulmonary capacity.

 

Option D. The risk of infection is heightened due to impaired immune function: Smoking suppresses immune response, making infections more likely, especially in the postoperative period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Smoking increases carboxyhaemoglobin, causing a leftward shift of the oxygen dissociation curve and impairing oxygen delivery. Smoking cessation (even just 12 hours before surgery) helps reverse this effect and improves tissue oxygenation.

questions.text: The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional Hudson oxygen mask is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 10 L/min

 

Explanation:

 

The maximum oxygen flow rate which can be kept with a conventional oxygen mask (Simple Face Mask, also known as Hudson mask) is 10 L/min. This is a standard setting for delivering oxygen to patients who require moderate levels of oxygen supplementation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5 L/min: While 5 L/min can be used, it is not the maximum flow rate for a Hudson mask.

 

Option B. 15 L/min: This flow rate is generally used with a non-rebreather mask rather than a conventional Hudson mask.

 

Option D. 20 L/min: This flow rate exceeds the capacity of most conventional oxygen delivery systems like the Hudson mask.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The maximum flow rate for a conventional Hudson oxygen mask is 10 L/min.

choices.text: MAC is a measure of anesthetic potency.
MAC values are lower in females.
MAC is decreased with acute alcohol use.

questions.text: Regarding the Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC) of inhaled anesthetics, which of the following statements is incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MAC values are lower in females

 

This statement is incorrect. Sex has no effect on MAC values - the minimum alveolar concentration is the same for both males and females. This represents one of several factors that don't affect MAC requirements, along with thyroid status and obesity.

 

MAC (Minimum Alveolar Concentration) represents the concentration of an inhalational anesthetic required to prevent movement in 50% of subjects in response to surgical stimulation. It serves as the primary measure of anesthetic potency, with more potent agents having lower MAC values.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MAC is a measure of anesthetic potency: This statement is correct. MAC directly correlates with anesthetic potency, with lower MAC values indicating higher potency.

 

Option C. MAC is decreased with acute alcohol use: This statement is correct. Acute alcohol consumption decreases MAC values, though chronic alcohol use has the opposite effect and increases MAC.

 

Option D. MAC increases during hyperthermia: This statement is correct, specifically for hyperthermia above 42°C. Extreme hyperthermia increases MAC values, requiring higher anesthetic concentrations.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While many factors alter MAC values (age, temperature, pregnancy, certain medications), gender has no influence on anesthetic requirements as measured by MAC.

questions.text: In a patient with chronic renal failure, which of the following anesthetic drugs is contraindicated due to the risk of toxicity? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pethidine

 

Pethidine (meperidine) is contraindicated in chronic renal failure due to the accumulation of its active metabolite, norpethidine. Norpethidine has a longer half-life than the parent drug and is neurotoxic, potentially causing seizures, tremors, agitation, and myoclonus. Since renal excretion is impaired in chronic kidney disease, norpethidine accumulates, increasing the risk of central nervous system toxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Morphine: Morphine does have active metabolites (notably morphine-6-glucuronide) that accumulate in renal failure, potentially leading to sedation and respiratory depression. However, it is not absolutely contraindicated—it can be used with dose adjustments and close monitoring.

 

Option B. Fentanyl: Fentanyl is the opioid of choice in renal impairment. It is metabolized in the liver and produces inactive metabolites, with minimal renal excretion, making it safe and predictable in patients with renal dysfunction.

 

Option D. Atracurium: Atracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker that undergoes Hofmann elimination (a temperature and pH-dependent degradation process) and ester hydrolysis, making it independent of renal or hepatic clearance. It is thus safe and preferred in renal failure, particularly during surgeries involving renal function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Avoid pethidine in renal failure due to the risk of toxic metabolite accumulation. Opt for safer alternatives like fentanyl and atracurium, which have predictable pharmacokinetics and are less dependent on renal clearance.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is used to reverse muscle relaxation induced by vecuronium? (INICET MAY 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neostigmine

 

Neostigmine is the anticholinesterase of choice for reversing neuromuscular blockade caused by vecuronium. When neuromuscular blockade needs to be reversed at the end of surgery, approximately 80% of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction are already free of vecuronium molecules. The remaining blockade can be reversed by increasing the acetylcholine concentration at the neuromuscular junction.

 

Neostigmine works by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, the enzyme responsible for breaking down acetylcholine. By preventing acetylcholine breakdown, neostigmine increases the concentration of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, which competes with the remaining vecuronium molecules and overcomes the residual blockade.

 

It's important to note that while sugammadex is the drug of choice for immediate and complete reversal of vecuronium (when full dose has been given and immediate reversal is needed), neostigmine remains the standard choice for routine reversal at the end of surgery. Neostigmine is typically administered with atropine or glycopyrrolate to counteract its muscarinic side effects such as bradycardia and bronchospasm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atropine: This is an anticholinergic drug that is used alongside neostigmine, not for reversing neuromuscular blockade itself, but to counter the extra-neuromuscular junction effects of neostigmine. Atropine prevents the muscarinic side effects of neostigmine such as bradycardia, increased salivation, and bronchospasm. It has no direct effect on reversing vecuronium-induced neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option C. Physostigmine: While physostigmine is also an anticholinesterase like neostigmine, it is not used for reversing neuromuscular blockade. Physostigmine crosses the blood-brain barrier (unlike neostigmine) and is primarily used for treating central anticholinergic syndrome and certain types of poisoning. It is not the drug of choice for reversing peripheral neuromuscular blockade caused by vecuronium.

 

Option D. Succinylcholine: This is completely incorrect as succinylcholine is itself a depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent, not a reversal agent. It would actually cause muscle relaxation rather than reverse it. Succinylcholine is used for rapid sequence intubation and short procedures requiring muscle relaxation, and would worsen rather than reverse the effects of vecuronium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neostigmine is the anticholinesterase drug of choice for reversing non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockade (such as that caused by vecuronium) by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase and increasing acetylcholine concentration at the neuromuscular junction.

questions.text: Among the listed muscle relaxants, which is primarily excreted via renal pathways? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pancuronium

 

Pancuronium is primarily excreted through the kidneys, with approximately 90% of the drug eliminated unchanged via renal excretion. Only 10-20% of pancuronium is metabolized in the liver, making renal clearance its dominant elimination pathway. This is why pancuronium is contraindicated in patients with renal failure, as impaired kidney function significantly prolongs its duration of action.

 

Table of Muscle Relaxant Elimination

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vecuronium: Incorrect because vecuronium has multiple elimination pathways. Only about 25% is excreted through the kidneys, while a significant amount (40%) is excreted in bile. Additionally, 30-40% of vecuronium is metabolized in the liver. 

 

Option C. Atracurium: Incorrect because atracurium undergoes a unique spontaneous degradation in plasma called Hoffman degradation, which is pH and temperature-dependent. This elimination pathway makes atracurium one of the muscle relaxants of choice for patients with renal failure since its clearance is independent of renal function.

 

Option D. Rocuronium: Incorrect because rocuronium is primarily eliminated through hepatic pathways (>70%), with minimal renal excretion.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pancuronium is primarily eliminated through renal excretion (90%), making it absolutely contraindicated in patients with renal failure, while other commonly used muscle relaxants have significant non-renal elimination pathways.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used for induction of anesthesia, maintenance and can be safely used in endotracheal intubation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sevoflurane

 

Explanation:

 

Sevoflurane is a versatile inhalation anesthetic that can be used for both the induction and maintenance of anesthesia. Its sweet smell makes it suitable for inhalational induction, especially in pediatric patients and others who might find pungent agents unpleasant. Sevoflurane also provides a smooth transition for endotracheal intubation due to its bronchodilatory effects and stable hemodynamic profile. Additionally, its low blood-gas solubility coefficient allows for rapid induction and emergence from anesthesia, which is beneficial in a surgical setting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Halothane: While Halothane can be used for induction and maintenance of anesthesia, it has a higher risk of hepatotoxicity and arrhythmias. It is also less commonly used in modern practice compared to Sevoflurane.

 

Option B. Desflurane: Desflurane is typically used for maintenance rather than induction due to its pungent odor and tendency to cause airway irritation. It also requires a special heated vaporizer due to its high vapor pressure.

 

Option D. Isoflurane: Isoflurane is primarily used for maintenance of anesthesia rather than induction due to its pungent smell and potential to cause airway irritation. It is less suitable for inhalational induction compared to Sevoflurane.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Sevoflurane is an ideal agent for both the induction and maintenance of anesthesia and is safe for use during endotracheal intubation due to its favorable properties.

choices.text: Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen for 3 minutes is done.
High-volume low-pressure cuff Endotracheal tube is used.
It is the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients.
Induction agent and muscle relaxant are given simultaneously.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement in rapid sequence intubation? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients.


Incorrect statement. Rapid sequence intubation typically involves administering an induction agent and a neuromuscular blocking agent to facilitate endotracheal intubation without the risk of aspiration. However, in cardiac arrest patients, the priority is to secure the airway quickly without delay. Often, these patients do not require medications for intubation as they are unresponsive and without protective reflexes. Also, chest compressions and defibrillation (if indicated) are of higher priority.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen for 3 minutes is done:
Correct statement. Preoxygenation with 100% oxygen before RSI helps to denitrogenate the lungs, ensuring that the patient has an adequate oxygen reserve during the apneic period (the time between paralysis and successful intubation). The goal is to delay the onset of hypoxemia during the apnea.

 

Option B. High-volume low-pressure cuff Endotracheal tube is used:
Correct statement. A high-volume low-pressure cuff on the endotracheal tube distributes the pressure over a larger area of the tracheal mucosa. This minimizes the risk of tracheal injury or necrosis.

 

Option D. Induction agent and muscle relaxant are given simultaneously:
Correct statement. In RSI, immediately after administering the induction agent (to render the patient unconscious), a neuromuscular blocking agent (muscle relaxant) is given to paralyze the patient, thus facilitating endotracheal intubation. This rapid administration of drugs is to minimize the time between loss of protective reflexes and securing the airway, hence reducing the risk of aspiration.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Rapid sequence intubation is not the method of choice in cardiac arrest patients due to the need for immediate airway management and ongoing chest compressions, making drug administration less critical.

questions.text: Which of the following anesthetic agents is associated with an increase in intracranial pressure (ICP)? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sevoflurane

 

Sevoflurane, like other inhaled anesthetic agents, causes vasodilation of cerebral blood vessels, leading to increased cerebral blood flow (CBF) and consequently increased intracranial pressure (ICP). All inhalational agents including sevoflurane increase cerebral blood flow and hence ICP. 
 

 Table of Anesthetic Agents and ICP Effects

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thiopentone sodium: This is an intravenous anesthetic that actually decreases cerebral blood flow and intracranial pressure. It's commonly used in neurosurgery and for patients with elevated ICP precisely because of this property.

 

Option C. Lidocaine - This is a local anesthetic that has minimal to no effect on ICP when used at clinical doses. When used systemically, it may actually have a mild ICP-lowering effect.

 

Option D. Propofol: This intravenous anesthetic decreases cerebral blood flow, cerebral metabolic rate, and consequently reduces intracranial pressure. Like thiopentone, propofol is often preferred in neuroanesthesia due to this beneficial effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

All inhalational anesthetic agents, including sevoflurane, increase cerebral blood flow through vasodilation, which leads to increased intracranial pressure - an important consideration when selecting anesthetics for neurosurgical procedures.

questions.text: During resuscitation in a patient with severe hypotension and cardiac arrhythmias, a patient received a 20% Intralipid injection. What could have been the most probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Local anesthesia toxicity

 

Intralipid (20% lipid emulsion) is used as a treatment for local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST). If a patient accidentally receives an excessive dose of local anesthetic, or if the local anesthetic is inadvertently injected into a blood vessel, it can lead to systemic toxicity, manifesting as CNS symptoms (like seizures) and cardiovascular collapse. Intralipid acts as a lipid sink, effectively reducing the concentration of the local anesthetic in the plasma and thereby reversing the toxic effects. This is why this option is the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Asphyxia due to drowning: While drowning can certainly lead to hypotension and arrhythmias, it does so because of hypoxia and other related complications. Intralipid injection is not a recognized treatment for drowning and its consequences.

 

Option C. Electrocution: While electrocution can cause cardiac arrhythmias and other cardiac problems, the primary treatment is to address the rhythm disturbances directly, treat burns, and support the patient. Intralipid would not be used in this context.

 

Option D. Pulseless electrical activity (PEA): PEA refers to a condition where there is organized or semi-organized electrical activity in the heart (seen on EKG) but no palpable pulse. The treatment for PEA is high-quality CPR, following the advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) algorithm, and addressing any potential reversible causes. Intralipid is not a standard treatment for PEA.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Intralipid (20% lipid emulsion) is used specifically for treating local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) by acting as a lipid sink to reduce the concentration of the local anesthetic in the plasma.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 885

questions.text:
Which of these are the components of high-quality CPR? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

a) Compression rate 100-120/min

b) Depth of compression in adults is 3-4 cm

c) Ventilation of 2 breaths for every 30 compressions

d) Allow complete chest recoil
questions.solution:
Ans. D) a, c & d

 

High-quality CPR in adults requires several critical components to be effective. These include:

 

a. Compression Rate: The compression rate should be between 100-120 compressions per minute. This rate is optimal to maintain blood flow during cardiac arrest.

 

b. Depth of Compression: For adults, the correct depth of compression is at least 2 inches (approximately 5 cm). The depth mentioned in the option B (3-4 cm) is incorrect as it is insufficient to generate adequate blood flow.

 

c. Ventilation: The recommended ventilation ratio is 2 breaths for every 30 compressions if no advanced airway is in place. This ensures adequate oxygenation during CPR.

 

d. Chest Recoil: Allowing complete chest recoil after each compression is essential. This allows the heart to refill with blood between compressions, which is crucial for effective circulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For high-quality CPR in adults, ensure a compression rate of 100-120/min, a compression depth of at least 2 inches (5 cm), a ventilation ratio of 30:2, and allow complete chest recoil between compressions.

choices.text: Block sodium channels
Block potassium channels
Block calcium channels
Block chloride channels

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of local anesthetics?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Block sodium channels

 

  • Mechanism: Local anesthetics primarily act by blocking the sodium channels bound to the membrane of the nerve, thus inhibiting sodium influx into the nerve and avoiding depolarization of the nerve.
  • States of Sodium Channels: The voltage-gated sodium channels exist in three states:
    • Resting (non-conducting)
    • Open (conducting)
    • Inactivated (non-conducting)
  • Affinity: Local anesthetics have maximum affinity for the sodium channels in the inactivated state.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Block potassium channels:

Blocking potassium channels is not the primary mechanism of action for local anesthetics. Potassium channels are more involved in the repolarization phase of the action potential.

 

Option C. Block calcium channels:

Blocking calcium channels is not the primary mechanism of action for local anesthetics. Calcium channels are more involved in neurotransmitter release at synapses.

 

Option D. Block chloride channels:

Blocking chloride channels is not the primary mechanism of action for local anesthetics. Chloride channels are typically associated with inhibitory neurotransmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Local anesthetics work by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels, which prevents the influx of sodium ions into nerve cells, thereby inhibiting nerve depolarization and the propagation of action potentials.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 871

choices.text: Paralysis lasting more than 1 to 3 hours

questions.text: In a patient with a normal quantity of pseudocholinesterase and a dibucaine number of 50, what is the likely duration of paralysis following a 1 mg/kg dose of intravenous succinylcholine? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Paralysis lasting 20 to 30 minutes

 

A dibucaine number of 50% indicates a heterozygous atypical pseudocholinesterase enzyme. While normal individuals (dibucaine number ~80%) metabolize succinylcholine rapidly with paralysis lasting 9-14 minutes, patients with heterozygous atypical enzyme (dibucaine number around 50%) experience intermediate prolongation of neuromuscular blockade. This intermediate enzyme activity results in paralysis lasting approximately 20-30 minutes - longer than normal but not as prolonged as in homozygous atypical cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperkalemic cardiac arrest:  This is a potential complication of succinylcholine in patients with denervation, burns, or muscular dystrophies, but is not directly related to pseudocholinesterase activity or dibucaine number.

 

Option B. Paralysis lasting 5 to 10 minutes: This represents the normal duration of action for succinylcholine in patients with normal pseudocholinesterase activity and normal dibucaine number (~80%). The patient with a Dibucine number of 50% will have a longer duration.

 

Option D. Paralysis lasting more than 1 to 3 hours: This extremely prolonged duration would be seen in homozygous atypical patients with dibucaine numbers around 20%. Since our patient has an intermediate dibucaine number of 50%, the paralysis will be intermediate in duration.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A dibucaine number of 50% indicates heterozygous atypical pseudocholinesterase with intermediate enzyme activity, resulting in paralysis lasting 20-30 minutes following succinylcholine administration - longer than normal but not as severely prolonged as in homozygous atypical cases.

questions.text: Which of the following medications may be safely discontinued with minimal risk of adverse effects before an abdominal surgery? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ACE Inhibitors/Angiotensin Receptor Blockers

 

ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) should be omitted on the day of surgery. According to pre-anesthetic evaluation guidelines, while most antihypertensive medications are continued, ACE inhibitors and ARBs are specifically recommended to be withheld due to an increased risk of significant intraoperative hypotension when taken on the morning of surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Statins: These should be continued perioperatively to maintain lipid control and vascular protection.

 

Option B. Beta Blockers: These should be continued on the day of surgery. Abrupt discontinuation can lead to rebound hypertension, tachycardia, and an increased risk of myocardial ischemia.

 

Option D. Steroids: Patients on chronic steroid therapy should continue their regular dose and receive supplemental IV hydrocortisone perioperatively. Discontinuing steroids can lead to adrenal insufficiency and hemodynamic instability during surgical stress.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While most chronic medications are continued perioperatively, ACE inhibitors and ARBs should be withheld on the day of surgery to reduce the risk of intraoperative hypotension. In contrast, beta blockers, statins, and steroids should be continued to avoid potential complications.

questions.text: Which of The following muscle relaxants injection causes maximal pain? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rocuronium

 

Rocuronium is known to cause the most intense injection pain among non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers. The pain is often immediate and described as burning or stinging, largely due to its low pH and osmolality, which irritate the vascular endothelium. Pain on injection can occur in 50–80% of patients when no pretreatment is given. To minimize discomfort, lidocaine pretreatment or administration after induction with propofol is commonly practiced.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Succinylcholine: Although succinylcholine may lead to postoperative myalgia, it typically does not cause pain on injection. Because it is administered rapidly after induction, any injection-related discomfort is rarely noticed.

 

Option B. Vecuronium: Vecuronium is virtually painless on injection. With a near-neutral pH, it is well tolerated and often selected when avoiding injection discomfort is important.

 

Option D. Cisatracurium: Cisatracurium causes minimal to no injection pain. It has a more stable pH and a lower propensity for histamine release compared to atracurium, its parent compound.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rocuronium causes the most injection pain among neuromuscular blockers, and pretreatment is often needed to reduce discomfort.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old male patient was undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Halfway through the surgery, a sudden drop in EtCO2 to 8 mm Hg was noted. His SpO2 became 90% and blood pressure dropped to 70/50 mmHg and peak airway pressure was 18 cm of H2O. What is the diagnosis?

 

  1. CO2 embolism
  2. Severe bronchospasm
  3. Pneumothorax
  4. Single bronchus intubation

 

EtCO2-End-tidal carbon dioxide
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1 only

 

Explanation:

 

1. CO2 embolism: During laparoscopic procedures, CO2 is used to insufflate the abdomen, creating a pneumoperitoneum. This allows for better visualization and manipulation of the internal structures. If there's a vascular injury, especially to a large vein, CO2 can enter the circulation and cause an embolism. This can lead to sudden cardiovascular collapse and a sharp drop in EtCO2, as observed in the scenario. Also, a sudden drop in oxygen saturation (SpO2) can occur due to the embolism obstructing the pulmonary vasculature. The significant drop in EtCO2, in this case, is indicative of a CO2 embolism.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Severe bronchospasm: Bronchospasm would lead to an increase in peak airway pressure, which wasn't seen in this scenario (the peak airway pressure was 18 cm of H2O, which is within the normal range). Moreover, EtCO2 would generally be elevated in bronchospasm due to retention of CO2, not decreased as seen in the scenario.

 

3. Pneumothorax: A pneumothorax could cause a drop in SpO2 and blood pressure. However, the EtCO2 drop to 8 mm Hg in the setting of laparoscopic surgery more specifically suggests a CO2 embolism. Additionally, one would expect an increase in peak airway pressures with a tension pneumothorax.

 

4. Single bronchus intubation: If the endotracheal tube is advanced too far and intubates a single bronchus, it would lead to ventilation of one lung only. This can cause a decrease in SpO2, but the sudden drop in EtCO2 as seen in the scenario isn't typical for single bronchus intubation.

 

Educational Objective :

 

A sudden and significant drop in EtCO2 during laparoscopic surgery, along with a decrease in SpO2 and blood pressure, strongly suggests a CO2 embolism.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1879

questions.text: Which inhaled anesthetic agent is preferred for pediatric induction of anesthesia? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sevoflurane

 

Sevoflurane is the preferred inhaled anesthetic agent for the induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients. This is primarily due to its pleasant, sweet smell, which makes it more tolerable for children to inhale. Additionally, Sevoflurane has a rapid onset of action, meaning it works quickly to induce anesthesia. This quick induction is critical in pediatric patients who often do not have an intravenous (IV) line placed before induction. The ability to induce anesthesia effectively and without distress is a significant advantage in this age group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Desflurane: Desflurane is not preferred for pediatric induction because it has a pungent odor, which can be irritating and unpleasant for children. Moreover, it can cause airway irritation, which is undesirable during induction.

 

Option C. Isoflurane: While Isoflurane is effective as an anesthetic, it also has a pungent smell and slower onset of action compared to Sevoflurane, making it less ideal for pediatric use.

 

Option D. Halothane: Halothane was previously used for pediatric induction, but it has largely fallen out of favor due to its potential for causing liver toxicity and its slower onset of action compared to Sevoflurane.

 

Educational Objective:


Sevoflurane is the anesthetic agent of choice for inhalational induction in pediatric patients due to its sweet smell and rapid onset of action.

questions.text: A child presents with acute respiratory distress. On examination, the abdomen was scaphoid. Which of the  following should not be performed in this patient : (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bag and mask ventilation

 

Explanation:

 

Bag and mask ventilation is typically the first step in managing respiratory distress to provide support. However, in the case of a scaphoid abdomen, which suggests the possibility of a congenital diaphragmatic hernia, this method can be dangerous. It could inflate the stomach and intestines, which may be in the thoracic cavity, thus reducing lung volume further and potentially worsening respiratory distress. Therefore, bag and mask ventilation should be avoided in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PPV with ETT: Although this can be cautiously used, it should be carefully monitored due to the risk of increasing thoracic pressure.

 

Option C. Oxygen therapy: This is a safe method to improve oxygenation without the risks associated with positive pressure ventilation.

 

Option D. Intubation: This is necessary for securing the airway and providing ventilatory support in severe respiratory distress and is safer compared to bag and mask ventilation in the context of a suspected diaphragmatic hernia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bag and mask ventilation should be avoided in a child with acute respiratory distress and a scaphoid abdomen, as it may exacerbate the condition if a congenital diaphragmatic hernia is present.

questions.text: A person has suffered from chest trauma resulting in fracture of 2-6th ribs. He is being given pain relief by IV analgesic agents. Which of these blocks will be helpful in pain relief? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thoracic epidural

 

For multiple rib fractures (2nd-6th ribs), thoracic epidural is the most appropriate choice  because:

 

  • It provides effective pain relief by blocking multiple spinal nerve roots at once through a single catheter
  • The epidural can be placed at T4-T5 level to cover the affected dermatomes
  • It allows continuous analgesia through catheter placement
  • It provides stable hemodynamics
  • The epidural catheter can be used for repeated administration of local anesthetic for prolonged pain relief

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical plexus block: Only supplies the neck and shoulder region. Not suitable for rib fractures as it does not cover the thoracic dermatomes.

 

Option B. Supraclavicular block: This is a brachial plexus block that provides anesthesia to the upper limb. It does not cover the thoracic area or ribs.

 

Option D. Lumbar epidural: Provides analgesia below the umbilicus. Not suitable for upper thoracic dermatomes where the fractured ribs are located.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Thoracic epidural is the optimal choice for pain management in multiple rib fractures as it provides effective analgesia through continuous blockade of multiple thoracic dermatomes.

choices.text: Non-depolarizing and phase II depolarizing blockade

questions.text: In which type of neuromuscular blockade is a sustained response to a tetanic stimulus observed? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phase-I depolarizing blockade only.

 

In Phase-I depolarizing blockade (typical of succinylcholine at normal doses), there is a sustained response to tetanic stimulation without fade. This occurs because succinylcholine acts as an agonist at nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, causing prolonged depolarization of the muscle membrane. During Phase-I block, the neuromuscular monitoring shows characteristic features including absence of fade during tetanic stimulation

 

 

characteristic features including absence of fade during tetanic stimulation

 

Summary Table of Muscular Responses to Nerve Stimulation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Non-depolarizing blockade only: Incorrect because non-depolarizing agents (like vecuronium, rocuronium, atracurium) competitively block acetylcholine receptors and produce a characteristic fade during tetanic stimulation.

 

Option C. Phase-II depolarizing blockade only: Incorrect because Phase-II block (which occurs with prolonged or high-dose succinylcholine administration) actually resembles non-depolarizing blockade with fade on tetanic stimulation. 

 

Option D. Non-depolarizing and phase II depolarizing blockade: Incorrect because both these types show fade during tetanic stimulation, not a sustained response.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Only Phase-I depolarizing blockade (typical of standard-dose succinylcholine) produces a sustained response to tetanic stimulation without fade, which is a key distinguishing feature from both non-depolarizing blockade and Phase-II depolarizing blockade that both demonstrate fade

questions.text: What is the frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 50 Hz

 

Explanation:

 

This is the frequency typically used for tetanic stimulation in neuromuscular monitoring. A stimulation of 50 Hz for 5 seconds results in a tetanic contraction. If the patient is under profound neuromuscular blockade, no contraction will be observed. If there's some recovery from blockade, a contraction will be noted but may be weaker than in a patient with no blockade. Fade during or after tetanic stimulation can indicate incomplete recovery from blockade.

 

Tetanic stimulation is a method used in neuromuscular monitoring to assess the degree of neuromuscular blockade in patients who have received neuromuscular blocking agents (often used during surgeries to produce muscle paralysis). Tetanic stimulation involves giving a high-frequency series of electrical impulses to a peripheral nerve to cause sustained muscle contraction. The response to tetanic stimulation can help determine the depth of neuromuscular blockade and the presence of fade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 0.2 Hz: This frequency is more representative of a "single twitch" stimulation, where one stimulus is delivered every 5 seconds. It is used to monitor the initial onset and the later stages of recovery from neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option B. 2 Hz: This refers to a train-of-four (TOF) stimulation where four stimuli are given at a frequency of 2 Hz (2 stimuli per second). It's a common method of monitoring neuromuscular blockade, especially when assessing for residual blockade. A fading response in the TOF is indicative of neuromuscular blockade.

 

Option C. 20 Hz: This isn't a standard frequency for neuromuscular monitoring.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring is typically 50 Hz.

 

 

PATTERN OF NERVE STIMULATION:

 

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 1359

questions.text: A 70-kg patient arrives at the emergency department with acute pancreatitis and is subsequently transferred to the ICU. The patient is intubated and placed on a ventilator with the following settings: FiO₂ 90%, PEEP 12 cm H₂O, respiratory rate 16 breaths/min, and tidal volume 420 ml. An arterial blood gas (ABG) reveals: pH 7.33, PaO₂ 110 mmHg, PaCO₂ 58 mmHg, and SpO₂ 100%. What would be the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reduce FiO₂

 

Explanation:

 

The patient's oxygenation status is excellent with a PaO₂ of 110 mmHg and SpO₂ of 100% while on a high FiO₂ of 90%. Prolonged exposure to high FiO₂ levels increases the risk of oxygen toxicity and absorption atelectasis. Therefore, FiO₂ should be reduced below 60% once oxygenation is adequate. The elevated PaCO₂ (58 mmHg) with a near-normal pH (7.33) reflects compensated respiratory acidosis, which is acceptable in the context of lung-protective ventilation strategies. In ARDS, permissive hypercapnia is an accepted approach where mild-to-moderate CO₂ retention is tolerated to avoid volutrauma and barotrauma from high tidal volumes or aggressive ventilation. Thus, reducing FiO₂ is safer and more appropriate than increasing tidal volume.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase PEEP to 16:  Not required as oxygenation is already adequate; higher PEEP may risk barotrauma.

 

Option B. Increase tidal volume: Though it may help clear CO₂, increasing tidal volume in ARDS risks volutrauma; permissive hypercapnia is preferred.

 

Option C. Reduce respiratory rate: Would worsen hypercapnia, which is already elevated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ARDS, once oxygenation is adequate, FiO₂ should be reduced to ≤60% to minimize oxygen toxicity. Permissive hypercapnia is a protective ventilatory strategy that accepts mild hypercapnia to avoid ventilator-induced lung injury from high tidal volumes or pressures.

choices.text: To assess mobility of cervical spine
To assess mobility of atlanto-axial joint
For assessment of free rotation of neck before intubation
Inspection of oral cavity before intubation

questions.text: What is the main use of Mallampati Grading? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inspection of oral cavity before intubation.

 

Mallampati grading is a standardized system used to classify and evaluate the visibility of oropharyngeal structures. It involves asking the patient to sit upright, open their mouth as wide as possible, and protrude the tongue without phonation. Based on the structures visible, patients are classified into four grades (I-IV). This examination helps predict potential difficulties with laryngoscopy and intubation by assessing the relative size of the tongue compared to the oral cavity

 

 

Mallampati Score/Grading for Assessment of Airway

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. To assess mobility of cervical spine: Cervical spine mobility is assessed separately through neck extension and flexion tests, not through Mallampati grading.

 

Option B. To assess mobility of atlanto-axial joint: This is evaluated through specific neck mobility tests, not through oral cavity examination.

 

Option C. For assessment of free rotation of neck before intubation: Neck rotation is part of the overall airway assessment but is separate from Mallampati grading, which focuses solely on the oral cavity structures.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mallampati grading is a standardized technique for evaluating oropharyngeal structures during preoperative airway assessment and serves as one of the key predictors of difficult laryngoscopy and intubation.

questions.text: Which of the following local  anaesthetic causes hypertension?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cocaine

 

Cocaine: An ester local anesthetic that is also a powerful central nervous system stimulant. One of the well-known cardiovascular effects of cocaine is hypertension, due to its potent vasoconstrictive properties.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lignocaine: is an amide local anesthetic that is used to produce numbness during procedures and for treating various types of pain. It can cause side effects such as dizziness and low blood pressure but is not known for causing hypertension.

 

Option C. Bupivacaine: An amide local anesthetic known for its potent and long-lasting numbing effect. It can cause cardiovascular complications, but like lignocaine, it is more associated with cardiac toxicity rather than hypertension.

 

Option D. Prilocaine: Another amide local anesthetic, similar to lignocaine, and not commonly associated with causing hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cocaine is the local anesthetic known to cause hypertension due to its vasoconstrictive effects.

choices.text: O2 pressure in inhaled air

questions.text: You are in the operating room and notice the tracing in gray color waveform on this device. What does it indicate? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Capnography

 

  • Function: Capnography measures the concentration of CO2 in exhaled air over time, producing a waveform called a capnogram.
  • Components: Capnography equipment typically comprises a CO2 sensor, which can be placed in the circuit of a mechanically ventilated patient or near the patient's airway for non-intubated individuals (e.g., during procedural sedation). The CO2 concentration is then plotted over time to produce a waveform.
  • Waveform Analysis: The capnogram is typically divided into four phases:
    • Phase I: Baseline, representing inspired gas, which is ideally CO2-free.
    • Phase II: The expiratory upstroke, representing the beginning of expiration with a mix of dead space and alveolar gas.
    • Phase III: Alveolar plateau, where the CO2 concentration stabilizes, reflecting primarily alveolar gas.
    • Phase 0: Inspiratory downstroke, as the patient begins to inhale again.

 

 

  • End-Tidal CO2 (EtCO2): This is the maximum value of CO2 at the end of expiration, and it provides an estimation of the arterial CO2 concentration, although they may not always be identical due to various physiological and pathological factors.

 

Clinical Applications:

 

  • Confirming correct endotracheal tube placement.
  • Monitoring the quality of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR). A sudden rise in EtCO2 can indicate return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC).
  • Evaluating a patient's ventilatory status.
  • Monitoring patients during procedural sedation.
  • Detecting conditions like pulmonary embolism, bronchospasm, and hypoventilation, among others.

 

Limitations:

 

  • Factors like changes in cardiac output, changes in alveolar ventilation, and equipment issues can influence the accuracy of capnography.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Airway pressure: Airway pressure monitoring involves measuring the pressure within the airways, typically during mechanical ventilation, but it does not produce a CO2 waveform.

 

Option C. O2 pressure in inhaled air: Measuring the pressure of oxygen in inhaled air is not typically displayed as a capnography waveform.

 

Option D. O2 pressure in exhaled air: Measuring the pressure of oxygen in exhaled air is not typically displayed as a capnography waveform.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Capnography is a crucial monitoring tool in the operating room and other clinical settings, used to measure and display the concentration of CO2 in exhaled air over time, helping to assess ventilation, confirm endotracheal tube placement, and monitor the effectiveness of resuscitation

questions.text: Arrange the following anaethesia agents on the basis of their potency.(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Methoxyflurane>Halothane>Isoflurane>Nitrous oxide

 

Explanation:

 

Potency of Anesthetic Agents:

  • The potency of inhaled anesthetic agents is measured by their Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC). The MAC value is inversely proportional to the potency; lower MAC values indicate higher potency.

 

MAC Values:

  • Methoxyflurane: 0.16
  • Halothane: 0.75
  • Isoflurane: 1.4
  • Nitrous oxide: 104

 

Order of Potency (from most potent to least potent):

  • Methoxyflurane: With the lowest MAC of 0.16, it is the most potent agent.
  • Halothane: With a MAC of 0.75, it is less potent than Methoxyflurane but more potent than Isoflurane and Nitrous oxide.
  • Isoflurane: With a MAC of 1.4, it is less potent than Methoxyflurane and Halothane but more potent than Nitrous oxide.
  • Nitrous oxide: With the highest MAC of 104, it is the least potent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nitrous oxide > Halothane > Isoflurane > Methoxyflurane: Incorrect, as Nitrous oxide has the highest MAC and is the least potent, while Methoxyflurane is the most potent.

 

Option C. Methoxyflurane > Isoflurane > Halothane > Nitrous oxide: Incorrect, as Halothane is more potent than Isoflurane.

 

Option D. Methoxyflurane > Nitrous oxide > Halothane > Isoflurane: Incorrect, as Nitrous oxide is the least potent and should be at the end of the sequence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The potency of inhaled anesthetic agents is inversely proportional to their MAC values. Methoxyflurane, with the lowest MAC, is the most potent, while Nitrous oxide, with the highest MAC, is the least potent. The correct order of potency is Methoxyflurane > Halothane > Isoflurane > Nitrous oxide.

choices.text: Increase flow rate to 15 L/min
High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who was under home isolation after testing positive for COVID-19, develops breathing difficulty and is brought to the ER. The patient is alert and responsive, but his respiratory rate is 26/min. Room air Sp02 is 86%. He is administered oxygen through a non -rebreathing mask with a flow rate of 10 L/ min. After a trial of one hour, his SpO2 is 88%. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy

 

  • Mechanism of Action: HFNC can deliver warmed, humidified oxygen at high flow rates (up to 60 L/min or more), creating a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) effect, reducing nasopharyngeal dead space, and improving oxygenation.
  • Effectiveness: Studies have shown its effectiveness in treating acute hypoxemic respiratory failure in COVID-19 patients. Given that the patient's SpO2 didn't improve significantly with an NRB, transitioning to HFNC might be a logical step before considering more invasive measures like intubation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increase flow rate to 15 L/min: The non-rebreather mask (NRB) is designed to deliver high concentrations of oxygen (up to 90%). Increasing the flow rate may slightly improve the fraction of delivered oxygen, but it may not result in significant improvement in oxygenation, especially if the cause of hypoxia isn't just a low FiO2. Therefore, merely increasing the flow rate may not be sufficient to address the patient's respiratory distress.

 

Option C. Endotracheal intubation: Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation are invasive interventions, reserved for patients who are in respiratory failure and cannot maintain adequate oxygenation and/or ventilation with less invasive means. While this patient is hypoxic, jumping straight to intubation without trialing intermediate steps like HFNC might be premature, especially since the patient is alert and responsive.

 

Option D. No specific intervention necessary: Given the patient's low SpO2 and increased respiratory rate, no intervention is not an appropriate choice. The patient is in respiratory distress and requires further measures to improve his oxygenation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with COVID-19 and hypoxemia unresponsive to a non-rebreather mask, transitioning to high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy (HFNC) is a logical next step. HFNC can provide better oxygenation and is a less invasive option before considering endotracheal intubation.

questions.text:
Regarding the Transversus Abdominis Plane (TAP) nerve block, which of the following statements are incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)

 

  1. The landmark for the block is the Triangle of Petit.
  2. It can be utilized as the sole anesthesia for an appendectomy.
  3. It can be used for postoperative analgesia following a Caesarean section.
  4. It blocks the nerves from T4 to T8.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B and D

 

The Transversus Abdominis Plane (TAP) block is a regional anesthesia technique that provides effective analgesia for abdominal surgeries. TAP block is administered in the fascial sheath deep to the internal oblique muscle and superficial to the transversus abdominis muscle. It is very effective for producing analgesia for abdominal surgeries such as cesarean section and hernia repair. The block provides excellent postoperative pain relief but is not intended as a sole anesthetic technique for major surgical procedures like appendectomy. TAP block is commonly used for achieving postoperative analgesia rather than primary anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A : The triangle of petit is indeed a landmark for landmark guided TAP block.

 

Option C : TAP block is very effective for producing analgesia for abdominal surgeries such as cesarean section, making it highly suitable for postoperative analgesia following Caesarean section.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TAP block is primarily used for postoperative analgesia in abdominal surgeries like cesarean section, not as a sole anesthetic technique for major procedures.

questions.text: A child was being delivered oxygen by nasal canula at 3L/min. What is the FiO2 being delivered?  (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B.  30%

 

Explanation:

 

The fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) delivered by nasal cannula increases by approximately 4% for every 1 liter per minute of oxygen flow. Thus:

 

  • 1 L/min would raise the FiO2 to about 24%.
  • 2 L/min would be about 28%.
  • 3 L/min would be about 32%.

 

Given the options provided, the closest and most commonly accepted approximation for the FiO2 being delivered at a flow rate of 3 L/min through a nasal cannula would be around 30%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 25%: This FiO2 would typically correspond to an oxygen flow rate of about 1 L/min via nasal cannula.

 

Option C. 40%: This FiO2 would typically correspond to an oxygen flow rate of about 5 L/min via nasal cannula.

 

Option D. 45%: This FiO2 would typically correspond to an oxygen flow rate of about 6 L/min via nasal cannula.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The FiO2 delivered by a nasal cannula at a flow rate of 3 L/min is approximately 30%.

questions.text:
Which of the following equipment is required for putting intravenous cannula in a newborn?(INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. 22G cannula

  2. 24G IV cannula

  3. 5-mL syringe

  4. Adhesive tape

  5. Normal saline
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2,3,4,5

 

Explanation:

 

2. 24G IV cannula: This refers to a 24-gauge (24G) cannula, which is typically used for neonates and infants due to its smaller diameter, making it suitable for their small and fragile veins.

3. 5-mL syringe: While placing an IV cannula, it's essential to have a syringe attached. The syringe helps to test the patency of the cannula once it's in the vein (flashback of blood can be seen), and it also assists in gently flushing the cannula with normal saline to ensure it's correctly positioned.

4. Adhesive tape: Once the cannula is in position, adhesive tape or a securement device is necessary to stabilize and fix the cannula in place, preventing it from dislodging.

5. Normal saline: Normal saline is used for flushing the cannula once it's in place to ensure patency. It's also utilized to keep the cannula patent if it's not immediately hooked up to an IV line.

 

Other Option:

 

1. 22G IV cannula: A 22-gauge (22G) cannula is larger and may be used for older infants or children but is often too large for a newborn's tiny veins. Hence, it is not typically used for neonates.

 

Educational Objective :

 

For placing an IV cannula in a newborn, the equipment required includes a 24G needle, a 5-mL syringe, adhesive tape, and normal saline.

choices.text: It achieves maximum concentration in brain after IV infusion
Redistribution to adipose tissue and muscle is seen
The rapid decline in its effect is due to renal excretion

questions.text: Which of these statements is incorrect about Thiopentone? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The rapid decline in its effect is due to renal excretion

 

The rapid decline in thiopentone's effect is due to redistribution, not renal excretion. Thiopentone's ultra-short acting nature is due to:

 

  • Initial high concentration in brain due to high lipid solubility
  • Subsequent redistribution from brain to less perfused tissues like muscle and fat
  • This redistribution causes rapid decline in brain concentration leading to awakening
  • Continuous redistribution between highly perfused and less perfused lipid-soluble areas maintains this pattern
  • The process is independent of renal excretion

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. It is highly lipid soluble: Correct statement. This property allows rapid crossing of blood-brain barrier.

 

Option B. It achieves maximum concentration in brain after IV infusion: Correct statement. Due to brain being highly perfused and thiopentone's lipid solubility.

 

Option C. Redistribution to adipose tissue and muscle is seen: Correct statement. This is the key mechanism for its short duration of action.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The rapid decline in thiopentone's anesthetic effect is due to redistribution to less perfused tissues, not renal excretion, explaining its ultra-short acting nature.

 

THIOPENTONE

 

  • T - Thiobarbiturates
  • H - Hyperthyroidism
  • I - Inadvertent intra-arterial Injection causes vasospasm (treatment - flush with NS, heparin, lignocaine)
  • O - pH 10.5 (alkaline)
  • P - pH
  • Porphyrias (C/I)
  • Prolongation of QT interval
  • E - Epilepsy
  • N - Neuroanesthesia (DOC)
  • T - Termination of action - redistribution

choices.text: FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.8
FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.75
FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7
FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.75

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient has grade III ASA. Which of the following post bronchodilator PFT findings requires further evaluation of the lung function of the patient? (INICET Nov 2021)

ASA- American Society of Anesthesiology

PFT- Pulmonary function test

FEV1 - Forced expiratory volume in 1 second

FVC- Forced vital capacity
questions.solution:
Ans. C. FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7

 

This option shows a significant reduction in both FEV1 and the FEV1/FVC ratio. An FEV1/FVC ratio of less than 0.7 is a clear indicator of obstructive lung disease. Combined with the reduced FEV1, this suggests significant lung dysfunction that requires further evaluation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.8: While these values indicate some reduction in lung function, they do not meet the threshold for a definitive diagnosis of obstructive lung disease. The FEV1/FVC ratio is still above the critical cutoff of 0.7.

 

Option B. FEV1 < 0.85 and FEV1/FVC <0.75: These values suggest reduced lung function but not to the extent that is indicative of moderate or severe COPD. The FEV1/FVC ratio is below 0.8 but not yet at the critical threshold of 0.7.

 

Option D. FEV1 < 0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.75: While the FEV1 is below 0.8, the FEV1/FVC ratio is not at the critical threshold of 0.7, so it does not indicate significant obstructive lung disease requiring further evaluation.

 

Educational Objective :

 

As per GOLD criteria for COPD, FEV1 <0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7 are classified as moderate COPD and require further evaluation of lung function.

 

GOLD criteria for COPD is given as follows:

 

 

Abbreviations: COPD, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; GOLD, Global Initiative for Lung Disease

 

As per GOLD criteria for COPD, FEV1 <0.8 and FEV1/FVC <0.7 are classified as moderate COPD and require further evaluation of the lung function.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 950

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms explains the cerebroprotective effect of Thiopentone? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased cerebral metabolism

 

Thiopentone offers cerebroprotection primarily by reducing cerebral metabolism. It decreases cerebral oxygen consumption (CMO₂), cerebral metabolic rate (CMR), and intracranial tension (ICT). This makes it particularly useful for cerebral protection in cases of focal ischemia, where reducing the brain’s metabolic demands helps limit damage during periods of impaired perfusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reduction of vasospasm: Although thiopentone can have some vascular effects, there is no evidence that it reduces vasospasm. In fact, due to its high alkalinity, intra-arterial injection of thiopentone may actually provoke vasospasm.

 

Option C. Calcium channel blockade: Thiopentone does not act via calcium channels. Its primary mechanism is through potentiation of GABA-A receptors, increasing chloride ion conductance and leading to neuronal hyperpolarization. It also suppresses excitatory neurotransmission.

 

Option D. Free radical removal: There is no indication that thiopentone acts as a free radical scavenger. Its neuroprotective properties are attributed to its ability to decrease metabolic demand in the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiopentone provides effective cerebroprotection in focal ischemia by lowering cerebral metabolic rate and oxygen consumption, thus reducing the brain's oxygen demand during compromised blood flow.

questions.text:
What are the indicators that suggest CPR is of high quality? (INICET May 2023)

 

1. Chest compression at a rate of 100-120/minute

2. Breathing rate of 20-25/minute

3. Depth of compression should be 5-6 cm

4. Allow chest recoil
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 4 only

 

Explanation:

 

High-Quality CPR Indicators:

 

1. Chest Compression Rate: Chest compressions should be performed at a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute.

 

3. Depth of Compression: Compressions should have a depth of 5-6 centimeters (2-2.4 inches).

 

4. Chest Recoil: It is essential to allow the chest to fully recoil after each compression to ensure adequate filling of the heart between compressions. If an advanced airway, such as an endotracheal tube or supraglottic airway device, is in place, the recommended ventilation rate is 10 breaths per minute.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2, 3 only: While a compression depth of 5-6 cm is correct, a breathing rate of 20-25/minute is not part of the indicators for high-quality CPR.

 

Option C. 1, 2, 3, 4: Although chest compression rate, depth, and recoil are correct indicators, the breathing rate of 20-25/minute is not recommended for high-quality CPR.

 

Option D. 1 only: While the correct chest compression rate is part of high-quality CPR, other factors like compression depth and chest recoil are also crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Effective CPR involves chest compressions performed at a rate between 100 to 120 compressions per minute and at a depth of 5 to 6 centimeters, allowing the chest to fully recoil after each compression. The recommended compression-to-ventilation ratio is 30:2 without an advanced airway, and 10 breaths per minute if an advanced airway is in place.

choices.text: Severe illness which is  constant threat to life

questions.text: Which of the following criteria corresponding to ASA grade III? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Severe illness

 

Explanation:

 

Option D. Severe illness: The American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Physical Status Classification System is used to assess and communicate a patient's pre-anesthesia medical co-morbidities. ASA grade III is defined as a patient with severe systemic disease that is not incapacitating. This means the patient has a serious illness, but it does not necessarily pose a constant threat to life, which would correspond to ASA IV.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option A. Mild illness: This corresponds to ASA II, which is defined as a patient with mild systemic disease. It does not reach the severity required for ASA III.

 

Option B. Moderate illness: This is not an official ASA classification term. The closest would be ASA II (mild systemic disease) or ASA III (severe systemic disease).

 

Option C. Severe illness which is a constant threat to life: This corresponds to ASA IV. It describes a patient with severe systemic disease that poses a constant threat to life, not ASA III.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ASA grade III corresponds to a patient with severe systemic disease that is not incapacitating.

 

The classification system is as follows:

 

  1. ASA I: A normal healthy patient.
  2. ASA II: A patient with mild systemic disease.
  3. ASA III: A patient with severe systemic disease that is not incapacitating.
  4. ASA IV: A patient with severe systemic disease that is a constant threat to life.
  5. ASA V: A moribund patient who is not expected to survive without the operation.
  6. ASA VI: A declared brain-dead patient whose organs are being removed for donor purposes.

questions.text: A 60 years old male patient was undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the surgery, it was observed that there was a sudden decrease in etCO2  to 8 mm Hg, SpO2 was 90%, BP dropped to 80/50 mm Hg and peak airway pressure was observed to be 18 mm Hg. Which of the most probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. CO2 embolism

 

Explanation:

 

In the scenario described, a sudden decrease in end-tidal CO2 (etCO2) to 8 mm Hg, along with a drop in blood pressure (BP) to 80/50 mm Hg and oxygen saturation (SpO2) to 90%, but with normal peak airway pressure (18 mm Hg), strongly suggests a CO2 embolism. During laparoscopic procedures, CO2 is used for insufflation to create a pneumoperitoneum, which can occasionally enter a blood vessel and cause a CO2 embolism. This event leads to a rapid decrease in etCO2 due to reduced return of CO2 to the lungs, hypoxemia, and cardiovascular collapse. The normal peak airway pressures help differentiate it from other causes of acute respiratory distress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: A pneumothorax, or collapsed lung, could occur due to barotrauma from mechanical ventilation or surgical complications. However, it typically causes an increase in peak airway pressures due to increased resistance to ventilation. The absence of increased peak airway pressures makes pneumothorax less likely in this case.

 

Option C. Endobronchial Intubation: Endobronchial intubation occurs when the endotracheal tube is inserted too far and intubates one of the main bronchi, typically the right main bronchus. This can lead to hypoventilation of one lung, causing a decrease in etCO2 and SpO2. However, peak airway pressures might be higher due to one-lung ventilation, which was not observed here.

 

Option D. Bronchospasm: Bronchospasm involves the constriction of the muscles in the walls of the bronchioles, leading to narrowed airways. This would usually present with an increase in peak airway pressures due to the narrowed airways, which is not consistent with the normal peak airway pressures reported in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During laparoscopic surgery, the sudden onset of hypotension, hypoxemia, and a significant decrease in etCO2 with normal peak airway pressures suggests a CO2 embolism, a rare but potentially life-threatening complication.

choices.text: Central line insertion
Arterial line insertion

questions.text: The given set of instruments are used in? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Airway management

 

Explanation:

 

The instruments shown in the image are part of an airway cart. The equipment typically found in an airway cart is designed for managing the airway during anesthesia or in emergency situations. The contents of the airway cart usually include:

 

  • Laryngoscope: A device used to obtain a view of the vocal folds and the glottis, which is essential for endotracheal intubation.
  • Tracheal tubes of various sizes: These tubes are used to secure the airway by passing through the trachea.
  • Masks: Various types of masks to deliver oxygen or anesthetic gases.
  • Laryngeal mask airways (LMA): A device placed over the laryngeal inlet to provide ventilation.
  • Flexible fiberoptic intubation equipment: Used for intubation in difficult airway situations.
  • Retrograde intubation equipment: Tools used for intubation when conventional methods fail.
  • Front of neck access equipment: Devices for surgical airway access.
  • Equipment required for emergency invasive airway access: Tools needed for emergency tracheostomy or cricothyrotomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central line insertion: This procedure requires different instruments such as central venous catheters, guidewires, dilators, and sterile drapes.

 

Option B. Arterial line insertion: This involves the use of arterial catheters, guidewires, and transducers, not typically found in an airway cart.

 

Option D. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR): CPR primarily requires defibrillators, chest compression devices, and basic airway management tools like bag-valve masks (BVM), but not the comprehensive set shown for airway management.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The instruments in an airway cart are specifically designed for various procedures involved in airway management, including intubation and emergency airway access.

questions.text: What is the most common cause for hospital admission after day care surgery? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Postoperative nausea and vomiting

 

Explanation:

 

The most common cause for hospital admission or delayed discharge from the hospital post day care surgery is Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV). PONV is a frequent complication following surgery and anesthesia, significantly impacting patient comfort and recovery, and often leading to extended hospital stays or readmissions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory distress: While it is a serious concern, it is not as commonly the cause for hospital admission after day care surgery as PONV.

 

Option B. Post-surgical pain: Although post-surgical pain is a common issue, it is generally managed effectively with analgesics and is less frequently the cause for hospital admission compared to PONV.

 

Option D. Bleeding: Postoperative bleeding can be a complication but is less common as a cause for hospital admission after day care surgery compared to PONV.

 

Risk factors for PONV:

 

 

Educational Objective :

 

Postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV) is the most common cause for hospital admission or delayed discharge after day care surgery.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 2603

choices.text: Increases the risk of malignant hyperthermia

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Total Intra-Venous Anesthesia (TIVA)? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reduces cerebral metabolic rate

 

Propofol, the primary induction agent used in TIVA, decreases cerebral metabolic rate (CMR), cerebral blood flow (CBF), and intracranial tension (ICT). These effects make propofol especially advantageous for neurosurgical procedures. When combined with remifentanil, it offers excellent hemodynamic stability and rapid recovery due to their short elimination half-lives. This combination makes TIVA particularly suitable for day-care surgeries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Causes increased renal toxicity: Propofol does not cause significant renal toxicity. It is primarily metabolized in the liver, with about 30% extrahepatic metabolism occurring in the kidneys and lungs. Its metabolites are inactive and do not accumulate to cause toxicity.

 

Option C. Increases the risk of malignant hyperthermia: Propofol is actually the induction agent of choice in patients susceptible to malignant hyperthermia, as it does not trigger this condition.

 

Option D. Inhibits hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction: This effect is more commonly associated with volatile anesthetic agents. Propofol has minimal impact on hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction compared to inhalational agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Total Intravenous Anesthesia (TIVA) using propofol and remifentanil reduces cerebral metabolic rate, provides stable hemodynamics, enables quick recovery, and is ideal for both neurosurgical and day-care surgical procedures.

questions.text: AMBU AURA40 is what generation LMA? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) First

 

AMBU AURA40 is a first-generation LMA because:

 

  • It has only one tube (the airway tube)
